steps.title: Assess the injury and stop using the finger immediately.
steps.content: Assess the injury and stop using the finger immediately. It’s important to stop using the finger for anything and let it rest after you injure it. No matter how you got the injury, stop what you’re doing and assess the injured finger. [1] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source Seek immediate medical attention if your finger: [2] X Trustworthy Source Seattle Children's Hospital Health information provided by Seattle Children's hospital. Go to source Feels numb or you cannot move it. Hurts, especially in the bones over the joints. Has red streaks extending from the injury. Has been injured before. Is cut or broken and the bone is visible. The skin is split and may need stitches. There is large swelling. There is blood under the nail or the nail has popped off. Dirt in the wound won’t go away after 15 minutes of scrubbing. The skin is cut and you have no past tetanus shots. Severe pain does not go away after 2 hours of taking OTC pain medication.

steps.title: Place the finger against a splint or clean popsicle stick.
steps.content: Place the finger against a splint or clean popsicle stick. If you have a minor sprain, you can splint it until you can see a doctor. Buy a splint in the first aid section of a drug store or use a straight, hard object. Choose something that is about the same length or slightly longer than the finger. A clean tongue depressor or popsicle stick works well. Once you have a splint, press it against the top side (dorsal side) of the injured finger and hold it there gently. Don't squeeze the finger or apply pressure to the injured area. [3] X Research source Make sure to position the splint under the injured joint. Depending on the type of injury or available splint, the splint may also go on the underside of your finger.

steps.title: Wrap medical tape around each phalanx, or finger bone.
steps.content: Wrap medical tape around each phalanx, or finger bone. Next, secure the splint to the finger by wrapping medical tape around it 3 times at 3 separate points. Wrap medical tape around the finger at the base of the fingernail (the distal phalanx or fingertip bone), the middle finger bone (middle phalanx), and above the knuckle next to the hand (the proximal phalanx). Make sure that the tape is snug, but still loose enough to ensure good circulation. [5] X Research source If you don’t have medical tape, you can also use regular clear tape. Taping each phalanx immobilizes the finger and prevents injured joints from bending and moving while they heal.

steps.title: Apply ice to the injured finger to reduce pain and swelling.
steps.content: Apply ice to the injured finger to reduce pain and swelling. Wrap an ice pack in a towel or paper towel and press it against the injured finger. Ice the finger for 10 to 20 minutes, and then remove it from the ice pack. Then, wait for the skin to return to its normal temperature before icing it again. This will take about 1 to 2 hours. [6] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source If you don’t have an ice pack, a bag of frozen corn or peas also works well. Just wrap it in a clean cloth or paper towel first. Never let ice or an ice pack come into direct contact with your skin. Icing is most helpful within 24 hours of receiving the injury.

steps.title: Take ibuprofen or acetaminophen for pain.
steps.content: Take ibuprofen or acetaminophen for pain. If the finger hurts, take an over-the-counter pain reliever, such as ibuprofen or acetaminophen. This will help you get some relief. Make sure to follow the manufacturer’s instructions for how much to take and how often to take it. [7] X Research source Keep in mind that the pain should start to subside after the first 24 to 48 hours. However, if the pain is worse or isn’t improving, call your doctor.

steps.title: Keep your hand elevated above the level of your heart.
steps.content: Keep your hand elevated above the level of your heart. Holding your affected hand above the level of your heart will help to reduce swelling. Prop your hand up on a pillow while you’re seated or lying down, or hold it up near your shoulder while you’re standing. [8] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source If the wound is bleeding, continue applying gentle but firm pressure with a clean gauze pad or clean cloth. If the bleeding does not stop, see a doctor right away.

steps.title: See a doctor for an injured finger as soon as possible.
steps.content: See a doctor for an injured finger as soon as possible. If you have a sprained or broken finger, call your doctor or visit an urgent care center for treatment. Your healthcare provider will assess the injured finger and apply an appropriate splint for the location and type of injury. They may also need to realign the finger before placing it in a splint, but they'll give you a local anesthetic to numb the finger first. [9] X Research source The sooner you get treatment for a sprained or broken finger, the better. Depending on the severity of the injury, it may take up to 3 to 4 months to heal. Delaying treatment can delay healing and lead to other complications, such as a skin infection.

steps.title: Get X-rays to determine what type of injury you have.
steps.content: Get X-rays to determine what type of injury you have. Your doctor will likely order X-rays to see if the finger is broken , dislocated , or sprained . This can help them to determine what type of splint will work best and whether they need to realign the bones before applying a splint. [10] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Let the healthcare professional apply a splint to your injured finger.
steps.content: Let the healthcare professional apply a splint to your injured finger. After your doctor reviews the X-rays, they can determine what type of splint will work best and apply it. There are different types of splints, and your doctor will choose the best option depending on the location and type of injury. Some common types include: [11] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source A mallet finger splint for correcting a finger that you cannot straighten. [12] X Research source An aluminum U-shaped splint for a distal phalangeal fracture. A dorsal extension block splint for a joint dislocation. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Get a tetanus shot and antibiotics if the finger was cut.
steps.content: Get a tetanus shot and antibiotics if the finger was cut. If you cut your finger, your doctor will likely recommend a tetanus shot to protect you against tetanus. They may also recommend a topical or oral antibiotic to prevent a skin infection. [14] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Get a tetanus shot within 48 hours of injury if you suspect contamination.

steps.title: Discuss surgical options with your doctor if the injury is severe.
steps.content: Discuss surgical options with your doctor if the injury is severe. If your finger is severely injured, it may not heal properly without surgery. Discuss surgical repair options with your doctor if they recommend surgery. However, keep in mind that this is uncommon. Most finger injuries heal well with a splint in about 4 to 8 weeks (but may take several months or up to a year if the finger is broken). [15] X Research source You may need surgery if your injury involves a joint, contains loose bone fragments or multiple fractures, there is tendon or ligament damage, or there is an unstable fracture that a splint can’t support. [16] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Cover the splint with a plastic bag when you bathe.
steps.content: Cover the splint with a plastic bag when you bathe. It’s important to keep the splint clean and dry. Cover your whole hand with a plastic bag whenever you take a shower or bath. Place a plastic bag over your hand and then secure it at your wrist with a rubber band. Use your other hand to wash yourself and angle your hand so that water won’t get into the bag. [17] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source Remove the plastic bag right after you finish your shower and pat your hand and the splint dry if needed.

steps.title: Wear the splint for as long as your doctor advises.
steps.content: Wear the splint for as long as your doctor advises. It may take up to 8 weeks for your finger to heal, depending on the severity of the injury. Keep the splint on during the day and at night until your doctor tells you it’s okay to stop wearing it. Not wearing the splint as instructed can lead to delayed healing or re-injury of the finger. [18] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source Depending on the injury, you may be able to remove your splint during the day after several weeks and only wear it at night to prevent injury or stress while sleeping.

steps.title: Check your finger daily to ensure that you have good circulation.
steps.content: Check your finger daily to ensure that you have good circulation. If you notice that your finger is an unusual color or if it feels numb, tingly, or painful, the splint may be too tight. Remove the splint by pulling or cutting off the tape and contact your doctor as soon as possible. If your skin is white when you remove the splint, it was likely too tight. [19] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source

steps.title: See your doctor if the splint feels uncomfortable.
steps.content: See your doctor if the splint feels uncomfortable. Never try to trim a splint on your own. If the splint feels uncomfortable or if it has rough edges that are irritating you, call your doctor and make an appointment. They can trim or adjust the splint for you to make it more comfortable. [20] X Research source Never try to trim down or smooth the edges of a splint yourself. Your doctor has special tools that make the job easier and less likely to damage or break the splint.
